WISCONSIN;

Getting The Freshmen Fresh
OUR MOST cordial greetings to you of the Class of
1938 and a few choice bits of advice. We assume that
all of you are here to derive as much as possible from
four years of college life in order to equip yourselves
for the harder battle that lies directly ahead. With
that assumption in mind, we counsel:
Enter upon your academic work with a free, open
and inquiring mind. Nothing that you should know will
be purposely withheld from you at the Hopkins. If you
don't quite comprehend, feel free to question. If you
don't agree, you will have every opportunity to voice
your own opinion. At the same time, !don't assume an
"I'm right, you're wrong" attitude. There's nothing an
instructor despises more thoroughlir.
Map out for yourself, with the help of your advisor,
a well-rounded schedule. Naturally, include those subjects which will prove of greatest assistance to you in
your intended vocation. Also see to it that you enroll
in those courses which will provide you with a better
educational background and perspective. And above
everything else, always keep correlating the knowledge
gleaned from your various courses, wherever any connection is, possible. In effect, strive to make your education one consistent panorama. The returns will be
heavy, if not immediately apparent.
Participate in activities if at all possible, but do not
do so if it means the absolute neglect of your scholastic
work. Too many students have sacrificed themselves
to the god of activity only to find that theirs was an
empty and malevolent deity. As in the case of studies,
select a variety of activities, even though your interest
may lie in one particular field. You will be surprised to
find what latent abilities you possess.

0.

Look upon your instructors as men interested in
your welfare rather than as human machines without
spark or animation. Seek their respect; cultivate their
friendship. Rid yourselves of the notion that all contact
between student and teacher should be confined to the
classroom, as is too often the conception derived from
high school experience. Consult them on any problems
which may arise, and see whether the overwhelming
majority isn't sympathetic and helpful.
Keep abreast of current events while in college.
Resist the tendency to restrict yourselves to problems
emanating from your text-books or the campus. Bear
in mind that history is being made every day, and, try
to follow the march of events.
'Nuf sed. Let's see you step!

absence, during which he did research work at the Institute.

Backfield Situation Uncertain
The backfield apepars extremely
uncertain this year with only two dependable performers of last year,
Captain Billy McClean and Charley
Kelly, sure to be in the ranks.
The status of Pete Reynolds, fleet
and elusive Blue Jay halfback, is still
questionable. Although forced to the
sidelines last year as the result of a
knee injury sustained in pre-season
practice, Reynolds was expected to
return to the varsity backfield for the
1934 campaign. As yet, however, he
has failed to register at the University, although he has been participating in practice drills almost daily.
The varsity season will open on
October 6 when the Black and Blue
travels to New York to oppose N. Y.
U. On following Saturdays Lehigh,
Washington, Haverford, Swarthmore,
Mt. St. Mary's and St. John's will be
encountered. The annual HopkinsMaryland game will take place on
November 29.

Getting The Freshmen Fresh
OUR MOST cordial greetings to you of the Class of
1938 and a few choice bits of advice. We assume that
all of you are here to derive as much as possible from
four years of college life in order to equip yourselves
for the harder battle that lies directly ahead. With
that assumption in mind, we counsel:
Enter upon your academic work with a free, open
and inquiring mind. Nothing that you should know will
be purposely withheld from you at the Hopkins. If you
don't quite comprehend, feel free to question. If you
don't agree, you will have every opportunity to voice
your own opinion. At the same time, !don't assume an
"I'm right, you're wrong" attitude. There's nothing an
instructor despises more thoroughlir.
Map out for yourself, with the help of your advisor,
a well-rounded schedule. Naturally, include those subjects which will prove of greatest assistance to you in
your intended vocation. Also see to it that you enroll
in those courses which will provide you with a better
educational background and perspective. And above
everything else, always keep correlating the knowledge
gleaned from your various courses, wherever any connection is, possible. In effect, strive to make your education one consistent panorama. The returns will be
heavy, if not immediately apparent.
Participate in activities if at all possible, but do not
do so if it means the absolute neglect of your scholastic
work. Too many students have sacrificed themselves
to the god of activity only to find that theirs was an
empty and malevolent deity. As in the case of studies,
select a variety of activities, even though your interest
may lie in one particular field. You will be surprised to
find what latent abilities you possess.

0.

Look upon your instructors as men interested in
your welfare rather than as human machines without
spark or animation. Seek their respect; cultivate their
friendship. Rid yourselves of the notion that all contact
between student and teacher should be confined to the
classroom, as is too often the conception derived from
high school experience. Consult them on any problems
which may arise, and see whether the overwhelming
majority isn't sympathetic and helpful.
Keep abreast of current events while in college.
Resist the tendency to restrict yourselves to problems
emanating from your text-books or the campus. Bear
in mind that history is being made every day, and, try
to follow the march of events.
'Nuf sed. Let's see you step!

to Homewood after a year's leave of
absence, during which he did research work at the Institute.

Backfield Situation Uncertain
The backfield apepars extremely
uncertain this year with only two dependable performers of last year,
Captain Billy McClean and Charley
Kelly, sure to be in the ranks.
The status of Pete Reynolds, fleet
and elusive Blue Jay halfback, is still
questionable. Although forced to the
sidelines last year as the result of a
knee injury sustained in pre-season
practice, Reynolds was expected to
return to the varsity backfield for the
1934 campaign. As yet, however, he
has failed to register at the University, although he has been participating in practice drills almost daily.
The varsity season will open on
October 6 when the Black and Blue
travels to New York to oppose N. Y.
U. On following Saturdays Lehigh,
Washington, Haverford, Swarthmore,
Mt. St. Mary's and St. John's will be
encountered. The annual HopkinsMaryland game will take place on
November 29.
